Agency: Office of the Comptroller of the Currency

Description: civil money penalty
Agency: Office of the Comptroller of the Currency

Description: Dain Rauscher Incorporated agreed to pay nearly $13 million to settle allegations arising out of the SEC's investigation into the practice in municipal bond transactions known as yield burning.

The Securities and Exchange Commission announced that RBC Capital Markets LLC would pay $30.4 million to settle allegations of misconduct in the sale of unsuitable investments to five Wisconsin school districts and its inadequate disclosures regarding the risks associated with those investments.
The SEC announced enforcement actions against 36 municipal underwriting firms for violations in municipal bond offerings.
The Securities and Exchange Commission announced the settlement of proceedings against 15 broker-dealer firms for engaging in violative practices in the auction rate securities market.

RBC Mortgage Company agreed to pay the United States more than $10.71 million to resolve allegations arising under the False Claims Act concerning 219 federally insured loans for mortgages submitted to the Federal Housing Administration of the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development. The government alleged that between 2001 and 2005 RBC, a subsidiary of the Royal Bank of Canada, falsified documentation in support of loan applications, violated due diligence underwriting requirements and improperly submitted loans for endorsement by HUD that were not eligible for FHA insurance.

The U.S. Commodity Futures Trading Commission (announced that a federal judge in the Southern District of New York entered a Consent Order for Permanent Injunction and Civil Monetary Penalty against Royal Bank of Canada for engaging in more than 1,000 illegal wash sales, fictitious sales, and noncompetitive transactions over a three-year period.
failure to disclose the risks of auction-rate securities

RBC agreed to return $850 million to investors and pay $9.8 million in civil penalties as part of the resolution of multistate litigation alleging it misled customers in the marketing and sale of auction rate securities.
Royal Bank of Canada agreed to pay a fine of $22,156 in settlement over allegations it misled investors about the safety of the aution rate securities (ARS) market.
Settlement of allegations of bid-rigging of municipal derivatives.
Info Source: State agrees on lawsuit settlement, Charleston Daily Mail, June 10, 2013 (via Nexis).

Description: The U.S. Commodity Futures Trading Commissionannounced an order filing and setting charges against RBC Capital Markets, LLC, a registered futures commission merchant, for failing to meet its supervisory obligations, which resulted in hundreds of unlawful trades and other violations over the period of at least late 2011 through May 2017.

Agency: Alaska Division of Banking and Securities
California Department of Financial Protection and Innovation

Notes: News release estimates $2.0 million restitution from settlement.

Description: RBC agreed to pay $9.8 million to a group of states to resolve allegations that it failed to properly warn investors about the risks of auction-rate securities. The settlement was also announced by the New York Attorney General; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-rbc-capital-markets-corporation-0
RBC agreed to pay $2.8 million to resolve multistate litigation concerning its practice of using unregistered personnel to sell securities.
Water Quality Control Act (including Surface Water Allocation)
Info Source: Contained in a spreadsheet obtained from the agency on October 7, 2020 in response to an open records request. The spreadsheet contains cases from the enforcement database accessible at https://enfo.gaepd.org/Orders/Search

Company: RBC Capital Markets LLC and RBC Capital Markets Arbitrage S.A.
Description: The Financial Industry Regulatory Authority fined 12 firms for significant deficiencies relating to the preservation of broker-dealer and customer records in a format that prevents alteration.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government.

Description: The Financial Industry Regulatory Authority ordered RBC Capital Markets to pay a $1 million fine and approximately $434,000 in restitution to customers for supervisory failures resulting in sales of unsuitable reverse convertibles.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government.

Description: The Financial Industry Regulatory Authority fined Ferris, Baker Watts LLC, acquired by RBC Wealth Management, $500,000 for inadequate supervision of sales of reverse convertible notes to retail customers as well as unsuitable sales of reverse convertibles to 57 accounts held by elderly customers who were at least 85 years old and customers with a modest net worth. The firm was ordered to pay nearly $190,000 in restitution to the 57 account holders for net losses incurred as a result of purchasing reverse convertibles.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government.

Description: The Financial Industry Regulatory Authority fined five broker-dealers a total of $385,000 for the illegal sale of more than 8 billion shares of penny stock on behalf of their customers. Most of those illegal sales involved one penny stock company, Universal Express Inc.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government.

Description: The Financial Industry Regulatory Authority imposed a fine of $1 million against Raymond James & Associates, Inc. of St. Petersburg, FL, and a fine of $400,000 against RBC Capital Markets Corporation of New York, for various stock loan improprieties.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government.

Description: The Financial Industry Regulatory Authority fined 19 broker-dealers a total of $2.8 million for substantially overstating their advertised trade volume to three private service providers.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government.

Description: NASD imposed fines totaling $850,000 against four firms for failing to have adequate supervisory systems and procedures to identify opportunities for investors to purchase Class A mutual fund shares at net asset value (NAV), or without a front-end sales charge.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government. This case was handled by its predecessor, the National Association of Securities Dealers (NASD).

Description: NASD fined three firms-and expelled a fourth-for violations relating to trading in corporate high yield bonds. All four firms were cited for charging excessive markups or markdowns in bond trades, as well as for supervision violations.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government. This case was handled by its predecessor, the National Association of Securities Dealers (NASD).

Description: NASD fined three firms-and expelled a fourth-for violations relating to trading in corporate high yield bonds. All four firms were cited for charging excessive markups or markdowns in bond trades, as well as for supervision violations.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government. This case was handled by its predecessor, the National Association of Securities Dealers (NASD).

Description: NASD imposed fines totaling more than $34 million on 15 broker-dealers in connection with the receipt of directed brokerage in exchange for preferential treatment for certain mutual fund companies
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government. This case was handled by its predecessor, the National Association of Securities Dealers (NASD).

Description: NASD censured and fined 29 securities firms over $9.2 million for more than 8,000 late disclosures of reportable information about their brokers, including customer complaints, regulatory actions, and criminal charges and convictions.
Info Source: NASD Fines 29 Firms over $9.2 Million for Late Reporting, PR Newswire, November 30, 2004 (via Nexis).
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government. This case was handled by its predecessor, the National Association of Securities Dealers (NASD).

Description: RBC Capital Markets LLC agreed to pay more than $800,000 to resolve charges that it engaged in unfair dealing in municipal bond offerings.
